A Cambridge Commencement's the time</br>When gentlemen come for degrees,</br>And with wild-looking cousins and wives</br>Thro' a smart mob of Pensioners squeeze.
The music that plays in the church,</br>Attracts them, tho' broiling the weather;</br>Like the good folks by Orpheus of old,</br>Who sat list'ning and steaming together.
Doctor Randal stuck up in the front,</br>(With the gay London fidlers behind)</br>Like a fine paper Punch pull'd by strings,</br>Throws his arms and his legs to the wind.
The pretty town misses have each</br>Some Sizar their humble beholder,</br>While the nymphs of the Lodge think there's nought</br>Like a bit of gold lace on the shoulder.
O'er the poor country curate's that's near</br>How their eyes (in fine language call'd killers)</br>They carelessly glance, till they rest</br>On the silk gown and long nose of V—.
But now to the Senate the troop</br>Perspiring and panting repair,</br>Where the good lady president sits,</br>Like a lobster that's boil'd, in the chair.
And there the gruff father of physic,</br>And the dark little father of law,</br>Stretch their hands o'er their children, and there</br>Divinity's lion his paw.
With kisses, with rings, and with hugs,</br>The old gentlemen treat one another,</br>Till by magic of hugs they become</br>From a son, in a moment a brother.
Miss, who sits in the gallery above,</br>Declares she conceives not the fun!</br>Nor how kisses and hugs make a brother,</br>Tho' she knows they have oft made a son.
Fair nymph, I'll unriddle the jest:</br>The kisses and hugs are by proxy;</br>The professors are but go-betweens,</br>'Tis old Alma Mater's the doxy.</br>
